graphicalElements.text: A group of young adults wishes to be served.  You are unsure if they are all of legal age.  Some look older than othersâ€¦   What do you do?
Not bad, but as you don't know who is drinking you need to check everyoneâ€™s photo IDs before serving alcoholic drinks.
Don't just ask their age. Check everyone's photo ID before serving any alcoholic drinks - Whether your boss is there or not!
Good job. It is always  better to check everyoneâ€™s photo IDs before serving alcoholic drinks..
Remember, minors are not allowed to remain in a bar area even if they are not drinking; also, anyone appearing under 25, has to show their ID.
Well done. If potential customers look under 25 years of age, taking precautions and politely asking for everyone's photo ID is a really good idea.
You're trying to figure out the friends' age which is a good idea. However, simply asking for their photo IDs is best to confirm their age.
A good start - you're getting there. Remember that clearly stating what the law says can help prevent situations from escalating.
A good start - you're getting there. Remember that clearly stating what the law says can help prevent situations from escalating.
It's not only about what they drink. Minors are not allowed in the bar areas, regardless of whether they are accompanied by a responsible adult.
Professional and diplomatic. You explained the law and approached them assertively.
You have stated what you 'have to' say and do. However, you must also comply with the law in practice!
You've stated the facts and managed the situation really well!
Your response is factual and helps prevent "second-party sales". To improve this refer to the under 18's signage and advice the underage friends need to be accompanied by a responsible adult.
